

<title> Thread Test </title>

<h1 id=results>Test Results</h1>

This page shows the results of repeating the <a href=threadtest.wiki>tests 
described here</a> using version 
<a href=https://www.sqlite.org/hctree/info/e842ed36acbae396>e842ed36acbae396</a>
on more powerful hardware. Observations:

<ul>
  <li> Write heavy transactions (update1, update10) using hctree scale
  reasonably well to about 44 threads. hct1024, which uses 1024 byte pages
  instead of the default 4096 bytes, appears to scale slightly better.

  <li> Write heavy transactions (update1, update10) using begin-concurrent +
  wal2 do not really even to 2 threads. As observed <a
  href=threadtest.wiki>here</a>, this is a difficult test for bcw2. That there
  are no read queries, and the database is small enough to fit in memory means
  that most of the time is spent in the serialized COMMIT operations, not in
  preparing the transactions.

  <li> For test cases that write, hctree and bcw2 (see update1_scan10), seem
  to become less efficient when the 2nd and 3rd threads are added, but then
  scale quite well from 4 threads onwards. See, for example, "hctree" in test
  case "update1". A single thread writes 49K transactions per second, 4 threads
  105K, and 8 threads 200K. It's not clear why this is - something to
  investigate.

  <li> Read-only transactions (scan10) scale well for both hctree and bcw2.
  This time bcw2 was consistently around 10% faster than hctree, which did
  not happen last time tests were run. Also something to investigate.

  <li> For a write-transaction with many reads (update1_scan10), bcw2 is able
  to efficiently use about 12 threads.

  <li> As <a href=threadtest.wiki>before</a>, hctree scales well with
  write-transactions that include many reads (update1_scan10), and balanced
  transactions that include both reads and writes (udpate10_scan10).
</ul>
